Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth nutrition
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 12/17/24 a quarterly unannounced visit occurred at the facility.
During interviews, two youth reported that if dinner is something
they are unable to eat, or do not like, they are not provided with an
alternate option. Youth stated they will go hungry as nothing else
is available for them. One youth reported she is unable to eat
pork, due to religious beliefs. The youth stated that pork is served
frequently, and she is not given another option.
Investigation Interviews:
Chief Administrator was contacted via email on 12/19/24 and
informed of the information received during the unannounced visit.
Chief Administrator was informed a special investigation would be
initiated to address the issue. Chief Administrator responded via
email on 12/27/24 and reported a meeting was scheduled
between the Unit Managers and Food Service to make a plan
regarding alternative meals for youth.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth A reported some of the food at the facility was “horrible”.
The menu was the same items over and over. They used to have
macaroni & cheese, but no longer had that. Youth A stated the
best thing was the spaghetti. The worst items were the burgers
because they were always cold and dry. Youth A reported pork
was served often, such as ham sliders and pulled pork. However,
she was unable to eat it due to religious beliefs. When pork was
served, there was not an alternative available for Youth A to eat,
and she went hungry for the night. Youth A noted a lot of the youth
in the program had triggers around food. Not being able to eat
could be traumatic for some youth. Youth A stated staff never
cooked in the facility kitchen and no food items were stored in the
kitchen, as all meals were prepared off-site. Youth A stated having
cereal, or sandwiches available on the unit would be helpful as an
alternative when pork was served. Follow-up occurred face-to-
face with Youth A on 1/17/24. Youth A reported the food situation
had not improved and there were not alternatives in place yet.
Youth A confirmed food service staff had a note on her file that
she could not eat pork products, but they do not always follow the
guide. Youth A indicated that she was recently served ham for
dinner and after reporting she could not eat it, she was given a
few extra sides of fruit, but that did not always happen as some
staff would request extras and some would not. Youth A did not
have any concerns about breakfast and lunch.
2

Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth B reported she did not care for some of the food and would
go without dinner at times. Youth B stated there were no
alternatives offered, such as a sandwich or cereal and there was
not food available on the unit. Youth B stated breakfast and lunch
were fine.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth C reported she did not have any complaints about food and
never refused a meal.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/25.
Youth D reported breakfast and lunch at the facility were good.
However, when dinner came to the unit at night, it was often cold.
If youth did not like what was served, or could not eat, there was
nothing else available and youth would not eat. Youth D stated it
has been that way as long as she has been at the facility. Youth D
reported there is not any food kept on the unit.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/25.
Youth E reported when meals arrived at the unit for dinner, they
were sometimes cold. If the food was something youth do not like
or could not eat, they had no choice. Youth either needed to eat it
or go hungry. Youth E stated she did not eat certain kinds of meat,
so she often did not eat dinner as there was always meat as part
of dinner. Youth E stated there were no alternatives and there
were no snacks, or any other food kept on the unit to supplement.
Youth E did not have any concerns about breakfast or lunch
items.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/25.
Youth F reported the food on campus was “disgusting”, and she
did not eat most of it. Youth F stated when the food was cold, or
not good, there was nothing else available to eat. Youth F stated
staff would not provide extra fruit or sides. There was nothing
available on the unit to eat. If youth asked staff to get something
else from the kitchen, staff refused. Youth F stated some meals
were not bad and cited breakfast and lunch as examples.
Breakfast was served at 7:00am, lunch at 1:00pm, snack at
4:00pm, dinner at 6:30pm, and a snack before bed. Youth F
stated dinner was often cold when they receive it.
Youth G was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth G reported the food was “nasty” and served cold
sometimes. Youth G stated she would often not eat dinner. Youth
G reported she did not have a special diet or anything, but she
3

would go days without eating because she did not like the food.
Youth G reported the bar-b-que chicken was good, as was the
breakfast. Lunch was usually fine, but dinner was “terrible”. Youth
G stated she would sometimes ask for extra sides or fruit, so she
had something to eat. Sometimes staff would provide that, and
sometimes they would not.
Youth H was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth H stated the food on campus was “gross”. Youth H did not
have anything she liked about it and stated she often did not eat.
Youth H reported no substitutes were available. If youth did not
eat, they would be placed on ‘food observation’ to be watched
when eating. Staff watched to see if youth were throwing up or
throwing food away. Youth H stated breakfast and lunch were fine,
but dinner was not good. Youth were not given any extra sides or
fruit as kitchen staff only sent enough for each youth.
Youth I was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth I reported food service did not accommodate her dietary
needs and told her it was because they ordered food in bulk.
Youth I stated she needed a high fiber diet due to stomach issues,
but she was served the same thing as everyone else. Youth I
reported she was offered fiber supplements in place of a high fiber
diet. Youth I did not like to take the supplements and refused at
times.
Youth J was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth J reported there were certain foods she could not eat due to
allergies. Food service had this information on file but did not
accommodate this and she was served the same as everyone
else. Youth J stated she had informed staff of her allergies, but
they told her she has to eat what is served. If the dinner item was
something she could not eat, she was given extra fruit in place.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 1 reported they were not aware of any youth being unable to
eat a meal. Staff 1 stated they were new to the facility and did not
work during dinner time.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 2 could not recall a time when youth did not receive a meal.
Staff 2 stated if youth did not like what was served, they would call
the kitchen for some soup, an extra snack, or something else.
Staff 2 stated they were aware of and followed all food allergies
and religious preferences. No food was kept on the unit.
4

Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Staff 3 stated some food was really good, but the youth were picky
about how things were seasoned and refused to eat. Some youth
also refused to eat because they were trying to lose weight. Youth
often later asked for something and would eat some extra fruit. If
youth did not like a meal, staff would check with food services to
see if there was anything else. Sometimes food services would
send up another snack or some fruit. Otherwise, meals were “take
it or leave it”.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Staff 4 stated when youth did not want to eat, staff would try to
convince them to. Staff did not want youth to feel sick or moody.
However, sometimes youth refused anyway. Some youth were
picky and would eat part of the meal, but not all of it. If youth
completely refused what was served, staff could call the kitchen to
see if there was something else available.
Staff 5 was interviewed by phone on 1/16/25. Staff 5 stated when
youth did not like a meal, they were given extra sides or fruit to
supplement. No food was kept on the unit and alternative meals
were not available. Some youth complained that dinner was cold
at times.
Rights Officer was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/17/24. Rights Officer stated youth received lunch in the café,
while dinner was sent to the unit. Youth with special diets were
reviewed by the nurse, who then provides meal information to
food services. The food services staff were not part of Vista Maria
and were contracted.
Chef was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25. Chef
reported food services was provided a list from nursing staff of any
youth with allergies or other special diets. Food for those youth
was prepared separately. For example, with Youth J, items such
as spaghetti sauce were prepared separately without the allergy
item in the sauce. The youth’s food was then marked that way and
sent to the unit. Youth ate lunch in the cafeteria where there was
planned menu item, as well as sandwiches, and a salad bar
available. If youth ate lunch on the unit, staff could call and
request an alternate item, but it was up to building staff to
communicate any needs. Regarding dinner, meals were packed
and sent to the unit at 4:30PM. Staff then decided when to serve
dinner. There were no kitchen staff available to contact after
5:00PM if meals were incorrect, or the youth requested something
different.
5

Documents Reviewed:
• Requests for Special Meals and Accommodations policy
revised November 2020. Policy indicates documentation
would be completed for any youth that was admitted with a
request for special dietary restrictions, health needs or
accommodations. Any newly discovered special dietary
needs or accommodations would be reported through
Health Services team and relayed to Food Service.
• Client Food Service policy revised February 2009. Policy
indicates if a youth refused a meal, it should be
documented in an incident report. If a youth refused a meal
but later requested food, she should be given something to
eat. If a unit’s food supply was not sufficient to meet the
needs of the youth, the shift supervisor should contact the
food department for assistance.
On-site Observations:
• A tour of the unit occurred on 12/15/24 at which time lunch
was observed. Youth were served a large loaded baked
potato. Youth on the unit reported they enjoyed this item.
No additional food items were found to be stored in the unit
kitchen.
• A tour of the food service area occurred on 1/17/25. Snacks
were observed to be packed and ready to go to the units.
Menus were observed to be appropriate, with a variety of
items. No alternative options were listed. A list of youth
food allergies and dietary needs was observed.
Analysis A violation was found based on interviews with youth and staff.
Although youth reported they received three meals per day, it was
consistently reported that dinner was either cold or youth were not
able to eat it due to special diets not being followed. Youth
consistently reported that alternative dinner options were not
available to them. This was verified by food services.
Consultation:
Consultation was provided to the agency regarding dinner service.
Food services staff indicated that meals were sent to the unit a
4:30PM. The kitchen then closed at 5:00PM. Youth reported not
being served dinner by unit staff until 5:30-6:30PM at which time,
the food is often cold and if the wrong meal was sent, there was
no one to contact to provide additional food to the youth. The
facility reported that food services was currently being reviewed.
As part of this review, the agency should address the timeliness of
dinner service, or proper procedures to hold or reheat food. In
6

addition, a process should be developed to provide simple food
items to youth at dinner time in the event they are unable to eat
the meal provided.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
